title: Whitespace options on HTML Exporter?
body:
So... the problem I've had with Discord, and what I was hoping this would solve, is that I don't seem to have an easy, automatic way to export or copy and paste chat logs from Discord to other applications--such as Google Docs or Kanka.io--and be able to preserve both the white space _and_ basic formatting options like _italics_ or **bold**. Every method I've tried, I've had to manually fix one or the other, and for the community I'm trying to manage, this is far too much work to do manually. Unfortunately, this exporter does not end up solving that problem for me.

Playing around with it, I found that the big issue comes down to the html exporter using a sort of "preserve whitespace" style to, well, preserve whitespace, and the programs I'm trying to copy into want to drop that like it's hot. Even tried a quick find/replace to get rid of the "class" attribute that ended up orphaned when the style got dropped, and replacing it with a "style" right on the tag itself to replicate the effect. Nope, programs dropped that too. Also, there isn't a good way to just find-replace all the line breaks with html tags automatically, because it creates _way_ too many new lines with the formatting.

With that in mind, I tried other options. HTML seems like it's the only one that's going to preserve the italics / bold type formatting, but I did notice that the .json programatically replaces newlines with a /n, so it seems like, potentially, most of the work for what I'm looking for is already done.

Would it be possible to create an option for, or a version of, the html exporters that takes a more active role in handling whitespace? Because if so it would _really_ help me out with what I'm trying to do. :)
author: Psiah-ence

comments.body:
I don't understand what you mean by "more active role in handling whitespace"? Replace newlines with `
` and spaces with ` `? That won't work with, for example, preformatted code blocks, which is why the preserve whitespace is used (and also why it's used in the Discord app itself). HTML is not meant for consumption by other programs, so sounds like either you're using the wrong tool for the job and should be using JSON, or the problem is with the programs you're using not being able to handle whitespace correctly.

title: How to translate mentions IDs to names
body:
Hey guys, 

So first of all, big props for what you are doing, much respect.
Second of all, I wish to inform you that this isn't an issue, more of a question that I seek the answer to.

So without beating around the brush for any more than I already have, my question:
As the title suggests, I am looking for a way to get the name or 'text' of the mentions in a message.

For example, if in discord the message with the text of  `@Vilian` may appear perfectly normal, the discord API returns it like this : "content : `815664984830771230`.", mentioned_roles ["815664984830771230"] 

But I saw that your application perfectly translates this into its original form ('@Vilian').
So, I cloned the repo and poked around the code for myself...However, my C# is kind of not on that expert level, so even though I looked through the files, I couldn't see how exactly you guys achieve this.

So yes, this is my question. How can I get the name of the mentioned role by having its ID.
Once again, this is not an issue with your application and I once again apologize for having to post this here.
I just couldn't find anywhere else an answer to my problem, (as far as I know, after reading Discord's developer portal docs, they do not explain it anywhere).

Best,
Vilian
author: Fractal-Tess

comments.body:
For roles and channels, DCE just pulls the entire list before exporting, and then cross-references it with mention IDs.
For users, it just keeps track of users that posted messages prior to the mention and cross-references it with that. You could also pull the list of users in a guild as well, but unlike roles and channels, their number may be much much higher.

title: Export format changes
body:
I have been exporting bulk messages on a weekly basis, and processing them in a google sheet that has been specially set up to handle the data directly copied from a .txt file. First, it was a bunch of extra header information at the bottom of the file for some reason, and now messages are exported with two carriage returns between each entry. Thank you for this awesome app.

The plain text format is not meant to be used for automation. If you need to consume output from another program, json is more recommended. There are also no breaking changes in json either.

title: Are there drawbacks to using a Bot token instead of a User token?
body:
Using the Bot is safer since it technically doesn't break Discord's TOS. Is it therefore just a blanket advantage over the User method, or are there drawbacks to using it?

If using the API, Bot's are limited to 100 API requests in a short period. Any more and it's classed as spam and can get your access revoked. Does this use the Discord API or does it merely "read" the channel like a User might?
author: I-Knight-I

comments.body:
Besides the tighter rate limits, when using bot tokens, you also can't get direct messages because they are not available using REST API.

> Does this use the Discord API or does it merely "read" the channel like a User might?

Not sure what "merely "read" the channel like a User might" means. I guess the answer is "yes" to both.

Apologies, I was just making simplified assumptions about the way the program works. 

Given Discord's rate limits, I expected the program to work similarly to if a User just scrolled-up on their chat logs - as opposed to fetching the messages from the API. Not sure what the reality is but I managed to use our bot just fine to get a full chatlog of 1000+ messages, so am happy.

Will close. Thanks

> Not sure what the reality is

It uses the same API in both cases.

title: Example command for getting direct messages
body:
While the following command works for general server channels, it fails for using the ID of a private message:
`docker run --rm -v ${PWD}:/app/out  tyrrrz/discordchatexporter export -t <token> -c <channel ID> -f PlainText`

It gives this error:
```
Exporting channel [259474169610240010]... Failed X

Unhandled Exception: DiscordChatExporter.Core.Services.Exceptions.HttpErrorStatusCodeException: Error HTTP status code: NotFound - NOT FOUND
```

Is there a specific flag I need to use for direct messages?
author: NerveCoordinator

comments.body:
For some reason, the channel ID that Discord copies when you click RMB->Copy ID on a DM channel is wrong.

If you want to get the actual ID, you can open the said DM in browser/app, open developer tools (Ctrl+Shift+I or equivalent), open Console, type `window.location.href` and copy the long sequence of numbers at the end of the URL.

Alternatively, you can get IDs of all your DMs in CLI using `dm` command -> `docker run --rm -v ${PWD}:/app/out tyrrrz/discordchatexporter dm -t <token>`

Okay that worked. However I had to copy the first sequence of numbers instead of the one at the end.
"discordapp.com/channels/@me/numbers/numbers"

title: What does the "message group limit" option do?
author: aeon3

comments.body: Messages sent by the same user, within the same hour, are grouped together - i.e. author name, avatar and date are shown only once, for the first message. Message group limit dictates how many messages can go into one group, at most. Setting this to 1 will disable grouping.

title: Deleted and edited messages
body: If somebody deletes or edits their message, will I be able to see the original in the logs after updating the logs?
author: bluefiberbread

comments.body: What do you mean by updating the logs?

Oh I thought if I exported a log from a channel, and somebody deleted/edited their message, and I exported it again, it'd show up as edited/deleted with the original message intact. I realized that's not the case now

No, it can't do that. But if you save logs separately each time, in plaintext, you would be able to use diff tools (e.g. WinMerge) to compare them and see if anything was edited or deleted since the last export.

6621c10ae06b3f0fbf41915f8a9d470a6cccd0fd

CLI (Command Line Interface)

When running CLI via Docker, per wiki instructions, DCE runs as root. This is true as of both the `stable` build, and the latest `Dockerfile` available at HEAD. (6621c10ae06b3f0fbf41915f8a9d470a6cccd0fd as of this writing)

title: Export message content without markdown parsing
body:
### Flavor

_No response_

### Export format

_No response_

### Details

I would like an option to export message contents in raw format. That is, by not substituting custom emote names (`<:name:id>`), channels (`<#id>`), mentions (`<@id>`) and so on. As it is now, the contents are converted to a human-readable format, but especially for JSON and CSV formats, it might be desirable to have the option to store the messages as they are actually sent. Discord markup is a subset of this that is exported raw in the text formats but parsed for HTML, so there is certainly a precedent for this. And it would increase the amount of information that could be gotten out of the exports.
I am using the CLI, but AFAIK, the GUI doesn't have an option for this either. For the CLI, I imagine it could be implemented as another option switch.
author: fghsgh

comments.body: What is your usecase for this?

One example would be downloading all of a server's custom emotes by sending a message containing all of them and parsing the `<:name:id>` format with a regex to get the download link and filename.

Another would be to have things like `#deleted-channel` actually give you more information than just "this channel was not available at the time of the data export", plus I tend to manually enter `<#id>` to refer to channels on servers other than the current one (which also shows up as `#deleted-channel`, even though it shows up fine in both the desktop and mobile clients).

Mentions of users can also be confusing because they could potentially have the same nickname, or they could change nick regularly. Plus, parsing these programmatically is just impossible anyway because these names could contain characters such as spaces as well, meaning you wouldn't be able to know where the name ended. And considering JSON is supposed to be parsed by a program anyway, I would expect it to behave in a program-friendly manner, retaining as much information as possible of the original message.

This last point is valid for all of them, really. In the JSON format (and all non-HTML ones, for that matter), how can I know if `:thonk:` is an emote or if someone just happened to type that text without it being an emote? How do I know, if I see `#general-chat`, whether the channel name is just `#general` and someone added `-chat` after it (not being part of the link, that is)?

Basically, as a technical Discord user myself, I am looking for a way to get the raw, plain text data of messages, for a multitude of reasons, which are certainly not limited to the ones listed above. I'd like to archive *all* the data, not just the data a normal user may find of importance.

Your title change to "without markdown parsing" seems to be a misunderstanding as well. I said that markdown parsing _is_ already disabled when exporting to non-HTML formats. I was talking about how some other, non-formatting things, are still parsed. I guess it depends on how broadly you take your definition of markdown.

I also have a use-case where this would be usefulâ€”rather than parsing channel ID references into channel names (potentially losing data if the program doesn't have access to the channel), it would be preferable to just save the message text raw.
#553 would fix this, but it was closed as wontfix; I think that the litany reasons provided, both here and in that PR, should be more than enough for Tyrrrz to reconsider.

The reason I'm against such feature requests is that they go against the fundamental purpose of the project â€“ which is to export and preserve conversations between people. The described use case above indicates that the goal there is instead to scrape all emoji from the server. This sounds like it would be outside the scope of the project, and I'd recommend just using Discord API to achieve that, which would also be easier too.

"scraping emoji" was only mentioned in the *first line* of my comment - quite literally not even the first 10% of bytes in that message. Please actually read what I have to say. The rest should have made it clear that I just care about archiving *all* of the data, including parts the exporter currently deems not important.
Ok, sorry, I didn't read the rest of it. Also, when I mentioned "markdown parsing", that included mentions and emoji too, as they fall under the same umbrella in the content of Discord.
From the UX perspective, we also don't have a way of providing format-specific options. We'd have to figure out how to introduce this aspect to the design.

In my opinion, JSON exports should out-of-the-box refer to all channels, emoji, users, etc. as IDs, since that's the purest form of the data. Converting all of those to text names is not really helpful for automation, and I believe actually is a hindrance since data is lostâ€”not to mention the complications that arise when names contain spaces. As for HTML exports, if we have any missing IDs we could add them as a data attribute on the corresponding elements. This way we wouldn't need to add an extra switch.

> In my opinion, JSON exports should out-of-the-box refer to all channels, emoji, users, etc. as IDs, since that's the purest form of the data. Converting all of those to text names is not really helpful for automation, and I believe actually is a hindrance since data is lostâ€”not to mention the complications that arise when names contain spaces. As for HTML exports, if we have any missing IDs we could add them as a data attribute on the corresponding elements. This way we wouldn't need to add an extra switch.

Makes sense. What about plain text format?

Honestly, I'm really ambivalent to whatever happens to the TXT format, because I don't find it very useful (to me personally) to begin with. If I had to guess, users who export plaintext archives are more interested in it as a lightweight option for presentation rather than automation, and it would probably be better to avoid swapping in ID's for everything. Might be best to just leave that the way it is now, since it's very information-light to begin with. As for CSV, I don't know if you have any interest in updating it at all given its obsolescense but I would consider that an automation format (i.e. one that would benefit from using raw IDs).

Happy to hear any other opinions on this though.

I have a use case for this I'm particularly excited for:

My D&D group uses Discord text channels/threads to do roleplay/dialogue sessions in a non-live format. Several of us keep session notes in Microsoft OneNote.

It is my intent to develop a CronJob that runs at 0001 every day, exporting all messages from the previous day in raw JSON to preserve all information about the messages. These dumps will be stored in GoogleDrive where all party members can access.

These JSON files would then be imported by a OneNote plugin I'm developing. Each user would be able to use the plugin to format the messages into their OneNote notebooks to their particular preference. This is why it's important to make no assumptions about format and download everything raw from Discord.
@matrumz why don't you just use the Discord API directly in your plugin?

That's a really good point.

The reason why I wasn't thinking about that is I know right now I don't have a ton of time to work on the plugin, but writing the CronJob that uses this tool for my k3s cluster is a 10 minute thing, and a python script to format it is 15 minutes, and we could use that until I got the plugin functional...

But you make a fair point: I can just do the really simple version of this in a v0.0.1 version of the plugin. 

I'll go that route for my work, but I would still think the feat requested in this thread would be high-value for any number of projects.

Thanks for your time & suggestions.

Another case for favoring raw data is for when you want to import this data in another application. There's a discussion going on writing a Discord -> Zulip data importer tool which could use this project as its base. That would be much easier if at least the JSON format gave all the raw data, since tools like Zulip have their own markdown parsers as well, and converting one raw syntax to another raw syntax is much easier.
This issue may also cover #415 #408

title: Text for broken embedded author icons overflows into embed contents
body:
### Version

2.28

### Flavor

GUI (Graphical User Interface), CLI (Command Line Interface)

### Export format

HTML

### Details

When saving an embed, Author Icons with broken links currently show the broken file icon, with the Alt Text below it, running into the contents of the embed. Preferred behavior would be to hide the image, either with a blank space (As Discord does it) or by just hiding the element altogether.

This was also discussed in Issue #533.

### Steps to reproduce

(I used a starboard bot to do this, but it should be doable many different ways)
- Create an embed with an Author Icon linking to a user profile picture
- Break the Author Icon link (I believe a linked user changing their profile picture will do this, but I'm not 100% sure)
- The image will not appear in Discord's embed. Exporting through DCE now should display the broken file icon and alt text.
author: CliffJameston

comments.body:
Adding `onerror="this.style.display='none'"` to the end of the embed-author-icon element should completely hide the element if the link is broken. Alternately, using `onerror="this.style.visibility='hidden'"` will also hide the element, while keeping the space where it should be (This matches Discord's formatting).
I can submit a PR in a few if you'd like.
Thanks @CliffJameston. Yeah, a PR would be welcome. Let's go for the second option to match Discord's behavior.

title: Export channels based on the GDPR data dump
body:
### Flavor

CLI (Command Line Interface)

### Export format

_No response_

### Details

Update the _exportall_ command, or make a new one, that takes the **index.json** file that a user obtained through requesting their data package from discord, the said file containing all the IDs of literally every DM they have had in their account lifetime (listed or closed, doesn't matter), and use it to read all the IDs and export all of the DMs, not just the currently open ones.

Since this app cannot request a data package on its own (especially since a data package takes hours/days/weeks to arrive), it would be much more suitable and simpler for it to merely use the **index.json** file that came from the request.
author: Auditormadness9

comments.body:
As a bodge, I made a quick script that helps achieve the same goal:

```python
import os
import json

# Settings
PROCESS_DMS = True
PROCESS_GROUPS = True
PROCESS_GUILD_CHANNELS = False

channel_ids = []
for folder in os.listdir():
    if os.path.isfile(folder):
        continue
    with open(os.path.join(folder,"channel.json"), "r") as f:
        channel = json.load(f)
        if ((channel["type"] == 0 and PROCESS_GUILD_CHANNELS)
         or (channel["type"] == 1 and PROCESS_DMS)
         or (channel["type"] == 3 and PROCESS_GROUPS)):
            channel_ids.append(folder)
print(" ".join(channel_ids))
```

Put this script in the `messages` folder of your takeout package, set the settings and run it. The output will be a list of channel IDs based on your settings that looks something like this: `106818467547163713 182588652098697417 289270027775765538 510326469454178206`.

You can then use it with DiscordChatExporter like this `DiscordChatExporter export -c 106818467547163713 182588652098697417 289270027775765538 510326469454178206 -t "..."`. The Linux command line has no problem running very long commands, so while it's a bit ugly to have hundreds of channel IDs on the command line like that, it should work just fine.

Slightly modified code if anyone needs it, because the previous one didn't work for me (I changed the channel type names). You still have to manually remove IDs from the list whose channel is unavailable though. Ideally make an attempt to access the channel directly from the script to check if its available, but I'm too lazy to do that.

```javascript
import os
import json

# Settings
PROCESS_DM = True
PROCESS_GROUP_DM = True

channel_ids = []
for folder in os.listdir():
    if os.path.isfile(folder):
        continue
    with open(os.path.join(folder,"channel.json"), "r") as f:
        channel = json.load(f)
        if ((channel["type"] == "DM"  and PROCESS_DM)
         or (channel["type"] == "GROUP_DM" and PROCESS_GROUP_DM)):
            channel_ids.append(folder[1:])
print(" ".join(channel_ids))
```
